com.hdcookbook.grin
Class Show

java.lang.Object
  com.hdcookbook.grin.Show

public class Show
extends java.lang.Object

Represents a show. A show is the top-level node in an enhancement. It is composed of a number of segments. A show progresses by moving through segments; a show has exactly one active segment while it is running.

addSegment

Used by the parser

activateSegment

public void activateSegment(Segment seg)
Set the current segment. This is the main way an application controls what is being displayed on the screen. The new segment will become current when we advance to the next frame.

This can be called from any thread; it does not take out the show lock or any other global locks. If the show has been destroyed, calling this method has no effect.

Parameters:
seg - The segment to activate, or null to pop the segment activation stack;

pushCurrentSegment

public void pushCurrentSegment()
Used by the activate segment command.

popSegmentStack

public Segment popSegmentStack()
Used by the activate segment command

runCommand

public void runCommand(Command cmd)
Run the given command when we advance to the next frame. If the show has been destroyed, this has no effect.

This can be called from any thread; it does not take out the show lock or any other global locks. If the show has been destroyed, calling this method has no effect.

setCaughtUp

public void setCaughtUp()
An xlet can call this method just before calling advanceToFrame if the animation loop is caught up. From time to time, pending commands will be deferred until animation has caught up. GRIN knows we've caught up when we paint a frame, but calling this method can let it know one frame earlier.

See Also:
advanceToFrame(int)

advanceToFrame

public void advanceToFrame(int newFrame)
                    throws java.lang.InterruptedException
Advance the state of the show to the given frame. Frame numbers monotonically increase; in the presence of trick play, they do not track the media time of the underlying video.

A show starts with the current frame set to -1, so the first frame is 0. When the show is advanced to frame 0, there might be a significant number of features that start initializing, e.g. by loading images. For this reason, an application might choose to use frame 0 as a special "initializing" frame that's never displayed, and that last for a fairly long time.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if newFrame < getCurrentFrame()
java.lang.InterruptedException - if the show has been destroyed
See Also:
setCaughtUp()

waitForFrame

public void waitForFrame(int wanted)
                  throws java.lang.InterruptedException
This is useful for an animation that wants to synchronize on certain frames in a show, using this pattern: 
      Show show = ...;
      int wantedFrame = ...;
      synchronized(show) {
          show.waitForFrame(wantedFrame);
          ...  make stateful changes to the show;
      }

Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException

getCurrentFrame

public int getCurrentFrame()
Get the current frame number of our underlying mode.

See Also:
advanceToFrame(int)

doActivateSegment

public void doActivateSegment(Segment newS)
This is called from ActivateSegmentCommand, and should not be called from anywhere else.

doSegmentDone

public void doSegmentDone()
This is called from SegmentDoneCommand, and should not be called from anywhere else.

getCurrentSegment

public Segment getCurrentSegment()
Get the current segment. The caller should probably be synchronizing on the show when using this, so that the current segment doesn't change right after the call.

setDisplayArea

public void setDisplayArea(java.awt.Rectangle thisArea,
                           java.awt.Rectangle lastArea,
                           java.awt.Rectangle clip)
                    throws java.lang.InterruptedException
Set thisArea to the union of lastArea and what will be displayed this time. Set lastArea to what will be displayed this time. A width of 0 indicates that nothing is drawn.

Usage: 

     Rectangle thisARea = new Rectangle();
     Rectangle lastArea = new Rectangle();
     Rectangle showClip = the bounding Rectangle of the show
     Rectlangle lastClip = new Rectangle();
     Show show = ...;
     for (frame = 1; ...; frame++) {
        show.setDisplayArea(thisArea. lastArea, showClip);
        if (thisArea.width > 0) {
            Graphics2D gr = the graphics to draw into;
            clear thisArea using gr.fillRect();
            Set gr's clip rect to thisArea;
            show.paintFrame(gr);
            Restore gr's clip area to what it was;
        }
    }
Doing this will optimize display by reducing the area cleared, and the amount of acutal drawing the show does. A concrete example of this pattern is in com.hdcookbook.grin.test.bigjdk.GrinTestRyan.

Parameters:
thisArea - The union of lastArea and what will be drawn this time
lastArea - What was drawn last time. Will be set to what will be drawn this time.
clip - The bounds of this show. The result that lastArea is set to is clipped to these bounds.
Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException - if the show has been destroyed

paintFrame

public void paintFrame(java.awt.Graphics2D gr)
                throws java.lang.InterruptedException
Paint the current state of the enhancement. This should be called by the xlet. This way, the xlet can decide to use whatever animation style it wants: direct draw, repaint draw, SFAA, or anything else.

Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException

handleKeyPressed

Called by the xlet when a keypress is received.

Returns:
true If the keypress is handled

                             int y)

                               int y)
Called by the xlet when the mouse is clicked.
